addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight, Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

18 Dec
e
b
1589 From M
r
Bodleigh at
e Hage.

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589
Novem
b
Decem
b
18
It may please yo
r
H.
e prisonner
Vasseur
is at length delivered, but w
t
very muche troble
and sute, as
e bearer herof
S
r
William Russels
servaunt, who hath folowed it long, w
t
exceeding
great paines, can certifie yo
r
H., who hath also
e copie of
e sentence, whereby they bannishe him
out of these Provinces, for
e space of 3 yeres.
By a servaunt of
M
r
Vicechamberlaine
I recea-
ved two from yo
r
H. three daies past: one
was of
e 26 and
e other of
e 28 of Novem.
and a third from my LL of
e Councell, of
e
12 of
e same moneth: wherein I am required
to declare unto
e
Generall states
, what order her
Ma
tie
hath taken, for repairing
e breaches of
e
sea at
Ostende:
whiche I minde to doe at their
next assembly, and will signifie their answear.
I have also made knowen to
e
Councell of state
her Ma
ties
licence graunted to my
L. Burgh
, for
his returne for a time, and for Cap
t
Price to go=
verne in his absence: wherunto they used no
speeche, but only sett it downe for a note in
eir
register. It is advertised hither out
of
Gelderland,
at the waters are risen so highe
in those quarters,
at
e Enemies fortes about
Bercke
and
Rees
are in daunger to be caried
away. About fortnight sins
e
Count
Harmon van Berghen,
finding a fitte opportunitie
by meanes of
e frost, made a roade into
Friseland
and burned a certaine Dorp, not farre from
Leward en.
But returning backe, as he passed by
a watche house, himself was hurt w
t
a muskett
shotte, and Villiers
e Governo
r
of
Steinwicke,
and
some fewe besides of his company slaine.
fol.195v
It freeseth at this present very hard in these con-
treis: and if it so continewe,
e English troupes
that are in
Holland,
must againe towardes
Gorchum.
Also this frost doth lette
e conveiance of letters
between me and
Joest van Cleve
at
Embden,
about
e mater of Groninghen, wherof I doe expect by his
next letter,
at I shall be able to conjecture w
at
good effect will ensewe. For he hath partly al-
ready broken
e ice, having written about it to some
principall persons
at are in Groninghen, who have
also returned a frindly answear: and procured
him a passeport of
e towne, to repaire thither unto
them. or otherwise they offer to send some fitte
person to Embden,
v
to c
o
ferre w
t
him there. And
it was his purpose, w
t
in six daies after
e dispatche
of his last unto me, Whiche was written six weekes
sins, to send my letter, wherof long sins I sent yo
r
H.
e copie, into
e towne: so as by his next, I
hope to have somw
at
of more worthe to advertise
yo
r
H. If those w
t
in, to whome he hath written,
doe not seeke to entrappe him (whiche he is cir-
cumspect enough, and wanteth no advise, to forsee)
there is sufficient cause to hope for a happy sequele,
or at lest of some distourbance in
e Enemies
courses. My writing in this mater to
e gentlemen
of Frise, uppon
Persivals
speeches, was a great
expense of time, w
t
out any fruite. For I attended
a great whyle for their direction, whiche proved
in
e ende to be
e same, as I had put in practise
before w
t
Joest van Cleve. It is
a good comfort unto me that yo
r
H doth intimat
of her Ma
ties
intention, at my
L. of Buckhurstes
comming hither, to make a perfect triall, howe
fol.196r
this people doth stand united unto her. I doe
finde it otherwise, for mine owne part, a most wea-
risome place of service, not knowing where her
Ma
tie
could send me, where
for mine owne part
I
would not goe w
t
more willingnes, and farre better
hope to give her Hig
nes
satisfaction w
t
some fruite of
my travels. I had never no hope in this place,
as yo
r
H. understoode me, of a perfect correspon-
dence. For I knowe it is impossible, as long as some
have
e sway. But I am forced heere to hold it
for a part of good correspondence, if her Ma
ties
sub-
jectes and ministers may be intreated in suche
competent good sort, as they may not be driven, by
meanes of their badde usage, to refuse to doe them
service. For by yo
r
H. letters heeretofore, and by
her Ma
ties
courses, I have alwaies found it esteemed
a mater of infinit daunger, if her Hig
nes
should
w
t
drawe her forces from hens: and yet unles her
Ma
tie
make shewe of some actual proceeding in
that respect, I see no other way, but that her Hig
nes
must perforce continewe her wonted pa
tience &
serve her owne turne for
e time, and
w
t
st
and
e
common Enemie w
t
suche a forward correspon-
dence as is heere at this present.
I have had no c
o
ference as yet w
t
Paul Bus
, to
whome
M
r
Gilpin
hath delivered yo
r
letter. He hath
many times made promise to come unto me: but his
aboade is at
Leiden,
and one thing or other doth put
him still from his purpose. Uppon
e receat of yo
r
H.
letter he hath appointed w
t
out faile, to be w
t
me
very shortly. But what he will impart, I can not
conjecture. He is muche discontented w
t
the state
aswell as others, and can better brooke of any man,
then of
Barnevelt,
who succeeded Advocat after
him.
fol.196v
Having nothing els at this present, wherw
t
to
troble yo
r
H. I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. De
c
18. 89
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
